Award.AwardTitle: NRI: INT: COLLAB: Soft Active Contact Pads with Tunable Stiffness and Adhesion for Customizable Robotic Grasping

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
As robots have a greater presence in our personal, public, and working environments, they must be equipped for a broad range of manipulation tasks and physical encounters. For many of these activities, such robots must be able to grasp a wide variety of everyday objects or be capable of physical interactions with humans or other robots. While there are robotic grippers ("end effectors") well-suited for specific tasks, progress in cooperative robotics has been limited by a lack of "universal" gripping systems that can handle a diverse set of objects. Universal gripping systems have the potential to dramatically improve robot performance and reduce costs by decreasing the number of end effectors that a robot needs for general purpose functionality. This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) project will address this critical need by creating new material architectures that enable universal robotic grasping. This will be accomplished by using materials that are capable of changing their mechanical properties such as stiffness and adhesion, and incorporating these materials into contact pads that the robot will use for gripping. This work will promote domestic economic growth and well-being by impacting multiple sectors in which cooperative robots will have an important role, including manufacturing, aerospace, agriculture, elderly care, and rehabilitation. This project will also contribute to educational outreach through middle/high school student workshops and science events that will inspire students to learn more about the role of materials in soft and human-friendly robotics.

The ultimate goal of this project is to realize a customizable robotic gripper that can operate in a broad range of contexts. To achieve this, the research team will pursue the following three interrelated research objectives. The first is to investigate the interplay between material stiffness, surface geometry, and the loading conditions that typically arise during robotic manipulation. This will include the development of adhesion-controlled robotic grasping approaches that exploit materials and structures with tunable stiffness and adhesion. The second objective is to engineer active contact pads that allow for high adhesive gripping forces and also high adhesion tunability. These pads will exploit a careful understanding of how material properties influence the distribution of mechanical stresses between contacting surfaces. The third objective is to integrate the soft contact pads into robotic end-effectors or the fingertips of a robotic hand. As part of this effort, the team will demonstrate enhancements in gripping performance and versatility through a comparative study involving objects with a broad range of shapes, sizes, weights, and mechanical properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the design and mechanics of soft active structures with dynamically tunable adhesion for the realization of customized and universal robotic gripping systems. The emphasis was put on handling of small and lightweight objects encountered in pick-and-place assembly processes of advanced electronics and precision devices. Approaches based on stiffness modulation and pressure modulation are both explored, with each having its own unique set of application scenarios. Through a combination of theory, modeling and experiments, approaches to tunable adhesives with significantly improved performance metrics, including the adhesion switching ratio, activation time, and activation pressure, have been realized. In particular, more than 100 times of adhesion change has been realized within a fraction of a second using low pressure roughly 10 kPa, which means the technology is very close to industrial adoption. Practical application of pressure controlled adhesion tuning was demonstrated through pick-and-place experiments on small-scale lightweight objects, both flat and curved. Certain efforts have also been expended on innovating novel smart materials for use in tunable adhesives. The primary intellectual merit of this project is the understanding of the design and mechanics of soft hollow structures with pneumatically controllable adhesion for practical robotic manipulation of small and lightweight objects. 


This work has technical broader impacts as it can enable automation of manufacturing processes that are currently manually done by offering new designs of compliant robotic gripping systems. Furthermore, the work has societal broader impacts that include the training of multiple engineering students at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoc levels. In particular, one of the graduate students has had the opportunity to intern at a company for half a year, gaining invaluable industrial experience that helps his entrance into the job market.  Last but not least, this project contributes to the education of the public and K-12 students about soft robotics and tunable adhesives through outreach efforts.


Last Modified: 03/23/2024
Modified by: Wanliang Shan

The emphasis was put on handling of small and lightweight objects encountered in pick-and-place assembly processes of advanced electronics and precision devices. Approaches based on stiffness modulation and pressure modulation are both explored, with each having its own unique set of application scenarios. Through a combination of theory, modeling and experiments, approaches to tunable adhesives with significantly improved performance metrics, including the adhesion switching ratio, activation time, and activation pressure, have been realized. In particular, more than 100 times of adhesion change has been realized within a fraction of a second using low pressure roughly 10 kPa, which means the technology is very close to industrial adoption. Practical application of pressure controlled adhesion tuning was demonstrated through pick-and-place experiments on small-scale lightweight objects, both flat and curved. Certain efforts have also been expended on innovating novel smart materials for use in tunable adhesives. The primary intellectual merit of this project is the understanding of the design and mechanics of soft hollow structures with pneumatically controllable adhesion for practical robotic manipulation of small and lightweight objects. This work has technical broader impacts as it can enable automation of manufacturing processes that are currently manually done by offering new designs of compliant robotic gripping systems.
